title: 112_hr2465
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Workers' Compensation Modernization and Improvement Act". It includes provisions for physician assistants and advanced practice nurses. The Act, titled the "Federal Workers' Compensation Modernization and Improvement Act," includes provisions for medical services provided by physician assistants and advanced practice nurses within the scope of their practice as defined by State law. The Act allows physician assistants and advanced practice nurses to provide treatment and certification for traumatic injuries within the scope of their practice as defined by State law, subject to regulations set by the Secretary of Labor. SEC. 3. COVERING TERRORISM INJURIES. Amends Section 8102(b) of title 5, United States Code to include coverage for injuries from terrorist attacks. SEC. 4. DISFIGUREMENT. Section 8107(c)(21) of title 5, United States Code now includes provisions for proper compensation for serious disfigurement of the face, head, or neck, not to exceed $50,000, in addition to any other compensation, for injuries occurring within a specified time frame. The maximum compensation for disfigurement under Section 8107(c)(21) of title 5, United States Code is adjusted annually on March 1 based on the cost of living adjustment. SEC. 5 amends Section 8116 of title 5, United States Code to allow the Secretary of Labor to require consent for the release of Social Security earnings information as a condition for receiving benefits. SEC. 6 addresses continuation of pay in a zone of armed conflict. Section 8118 of title 5, United States Code is amended to allow for the continuation of pay for employees in a zone of armed conflict, despite certain conditions. Employees in a zone of armed conflict can receive wage loss benefits for traumatic injuries if they file a claim within 45 days of returning to the United States. Continuation of pay can last up to 135 days without interruption, unless contested by the Secretary of Labor. The determination of zones of armed conflict is made by the Secretary of Labor. The Secretary of Labor, in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense, determines if a foreign country or area is a zone of armed conflict based on US Armed Forces involvement or threats to civilian employees' well-being. The Secretary of Labor, in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense, determines if a foreign country or area is a zone of armed conflict based on specific criteria such as combat zones designated by the President or contingency operations affecting civilian employees. SEC. 7. Subrogation of continuation of pay, amends Section 8131 of title 5, United States Code to include "continuation of pay or compensation" in subsections (a) and (c). Section 8132 is also amended to include "continuation of pay or compensation" in multiple instances and adjust language regarding recovery from a third person. SEC. 8 addresses funeral expenses. Section 8134 of title 5, United States Code is amended to allow the United States to pay funeral and burial expenses up to $6,000 for deaths resulting from duty-related injuries. This provision is effective for deaths occurring after the enactment of the Federal Workers' Compensation Modernization and Improvement Act. SEC. 9. EMPLOYEES' COMPENSATION FUND. Section 8147 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include administrative expenses and provide estimates for funds necessary for the next fiscal year. SEC. 10. CONFORMING AMENDMENT. SEC. 10. CONFORMING AMENDMENT. Section 8101(1)(D) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include individuals who suffered an injury on or before March 3, 1979. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment. SEC. 12. PAYGO COMPLIANCE. The budgetary effects of this Act will comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
